Idiom (Kituba): Kuna ntima na muntu me tula ve
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause with negative verb phrase
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Someone is restless or worried inside; not at peace.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common Congo-Brazzaville saying describing emotional unrest.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Kituba): [kù.ná ntí.má ná mùn.tù mè tú.là βé]
First Example Sentence: Beno mona ve, kuna ntima na yandi me tula ve banda yandi tangaka nsango yango.
Second Example Sentence: Ntangu mpangi na yandi me zanga, kuna ntima na yandi me tula ve.
Third Example Sentence: Kuna ntima na mwana me tula ve mpo na mayele ya ndoki.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To face a serious challenge or danger.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Comes from imagery of venturing into the heart of a mountain—traditional metaphor for difficulty.
First Example Sentence: Beto kota na ntima ya ngomba ntangu to salaka kisalu ya mbongo.
Second Example Sentence: Ntangu ndenge to zaba ve solution, to kota na ntima ya ngomba.
Third Example Sentence: Yandi me kota na ntima ya ngomba na makambu ya ndima.

Idiom (Kituba): Sosa mbwa na nse ya mesa
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Verb phrase with locative and object complement
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To search in the wrong place; a futile effort.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To look where there is nothing to find.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from everyday imagery—searching for a dog under the table where it never stays.
First Example Sentence: Yandi ke sosa mbwa na nse ya mesa na kisalu ya mbongo.
Second Example Sentence: Beno sala ve ndenge ya sosa mbwa na nse ya mesa na makambu ya lufua.
Third Example Sentence: Yandi sosa mbwa na nse ya mesa, ata yina ntoto me lomba.

Idiom (Kituba): Ntangu ke bima, mpunda ke zinga
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Every event has its right moment; patience pays.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: Be patient; time will reveal all.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common proverb in rural Congo; reflects patience and faith in timing.
First Example Sentence: Ntangu ke bima, mpunda ke zinga; beno vanda mpasi ve.
Second Example Sentence: Beno baka ntangu, mpunda ke zinga sambu na bantu ya makasi.
Third Example Sentence: Ntangu ke bima, mpunda ke zinga; Nzambe ke sala na ntangu na yandi.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To see things from another perspective.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: To consider someone else’s point of view.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Encourages empathy; common in educational and moral contexts.
First Example Sentence: Ntangu yo ke tula mambu, tala na meso ya nkaka.
Second Example Sentence: Beno longa bana na bino tala na meso ya nkaka.
Third Example Sentence: Tala na meso ya nkaka, yina nde kimia ke vandaka.

Idiom (Kituba): Muntu ya zulu me wa na nse
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Clause with subject and locative inversion
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: A powerful person has fallen from grace.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: A person lost their status or position.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Refers to downfall imagery; popular in postcolonial political satire.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Kituba): [mùn.tù yà zù.lù mè wà nà nsé]
First Example Sentence: Muntu ya zulu me wa na nse na ndenge ya mpamba.
Second Example Sentence: Yandi vandaka ntoma, kasi sikoyo muntu ya zulu me wa na nse.
Third Example Sentence: Tala ndenge ya ngambo, muntu ya zulu me wa na nse.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To blame the wrong person for something.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Comes from village justice imagery where dogs are often scapegoated for missing food.
First Example Sentence: Beno baka mbwa na lufu na makambu ya kisika ya yo ve.
Second Example Sentence: Ntangu lenda ve zaba muntu ya sala, bango baka mbwa na lufu.
Third Example Sentence: Kima ve ndenge ya baka mbwa na lufu, tala mbala mbote.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Originates from Kongo matriarchal oral traditions.
First Example Sentence: Beno leka ve na mbata ya nkento, yandi ke zaba ndenge ya mbote.
Second Example Sentence: Ntangu yandi pesa maboko, tala—leka na mbata ya nkento te.
Third Example Sentence: Beno tanga bana ya nkento mpasi ve, leka na mbata ya nkento.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: To end a relationship or connection abruptly.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Metaphor for severing ties visibly, often in interpersonal contexts.
First Example Sentence: Yandi kata lufu na meso banda na ntangu ya malanda.
Second Example Sentence: Ntangu mambu ya ve salama, bango kata lufu na meso.
Third Example Sentence: Yo kata lufu na meso na yandi, kasi ntima ke bola.

Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Since ancient times; from long ago.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Traditional phrase evoking ancestral memory and oral tradition.
First Example Sentence: Banda na ntangu ya mvuanda, bantu me baka mbote na ndinga.
Second Example Sentence: Nsango oyo me vandaka banda na ntangu ya mvuanda.
Third Example Sentence: Banda na ntangu ya mvuanda, bantu me yindula ndenge ya kiese.
